title: 70 Years to Solve
content:
Hilbert posed this problem in 1900, and it took 70 years and four mathematicians to solve it. The key breakthrough came from Yuri Matiyasevich in 1970, who was just 22 years old.

The solution required connecting two seemingly unrelated areas: ancient Diophantine equations (studied since antiquity) and modern computability theory (developed in the 1930s).
mathContext: Hilbert's challenge: Find an algorithm that decides whether any polynomial equation $P(x_1, \ldots, x_n) = 0$ with integer coefficients has integer solutions.

title: Diophantine Polynomial
content:
A **Diophantine polynomial** is a polynomial with integer coefficients in any number of variables. We model it as a function from variable assignments (each variable gets an integer value) to integers.

The polynomial evaluates to 0 when a valid solution is found.
mathContext:
$P : (\mathbb{N} \to \mathbb{Z}) \to \mathbb{Z}$

For example, $P(x,y) = x^2 + y^2 - 5$ represents the equation $x^2 + y^2 = 5$.

title: Diophantine Solution
content:
A Diophantine equation $P = 0$ **has a solution** if there exists an assignment of integers to all variables that makes the polynomial evaluate to zero.

The question 'does a solution exist?' is the core of Hilbert's 10th problem.

title: Diophantine Sets
content:
A set $S \subseteq \mathbb{N}$ is **Diophantine** if membership can be expressed via polynomial solvability.

Formally: $n \in S$ iff there exist integers $(x_1, \ldots, x_k)$ such that $P(n, x_1, \ldots, x_k) = 0$ for some fixed polynomial $P$.

The MRDP theorem characterizes exactly which sets are Diophantine.
mathContext: $S$ is Diophantine iff $\exists P : n \in S \Leftrightarrow \exists \vec{x} \in \mathbb{Z}^k : P(n, \vec{x}) = 0$

title: Recursively Enumerable Sets
content:
A set is **recursively enumerable (r.e.)** if there's a program that halts exactly on members of the set. Equivalently, we can list all members (possibly with duplicates, possibly not in order).

The halting set is the canonical example of an r.e. set that is not decidable.
mathContext:
$S$ is r.e. iff $\exists$ program $p : n \in S \Leftrightarrow p$ halts on input $n$

Equivalently: $S = \{n : \exists t . M(n)$ halts in $t$ steps$\}$

title: The MRDP Theorem
content:
**MRDP Theorem** (Matiyasevich-Robinson-Davis-Putnam, 1970):

A set is recursively enumerable if and only if it is Diophantine.

This is a stunning result: the ancient concept of polynomial solvability over integers captures exactly the modern notion of semi-decidability!
mathContext:
$S$ is r.e. $\Leftrightarrow$ $S$ is Diophantine

Every computable enumeration can be encoded as polynomial solvability.

title: Diagonal Behavior
content:
The **diagonal behavior** is the key construction for proving undecidability. Given any oracle $H$, the diagonal does the opposite of what $H$ predicts for self-application:

diagonal$(n) = \neg H(n, n)$

This creates a behavior that $H$ cannot correctly predict.
mathContext:
$\text{diagonal}(H)(n) = \neg H(n, n)$

If $H$ says program $n$ halts on $n$, diagonal loops.
If $H$ says program $n$ loops on $n$, diagonal halts.

title: Halting is Undecidable
content:
**Turing's Theorem** (1936): No algorithm can correctly decide whether an arbitrary program halts.

The proof uses diagonalization: for any proposed oracle, we can construct a behavior (the diagonal) that the oracle must get wrong.

This is the foundation for proving H10 undecidable.

title: Reduction: H10 to Halting
content:
The key reduction: from a correct H10 oracle, we can construct a halting oracle.

1. The halting set for any program is r.e.
2. By MRDP, every r.e. set is Diophantine.
3. So we can encode 'does program p halt on n?' as a Diophantine equation.
4. Ask the H10 oracle if this equation has solutions.

If H10 were decidable, halting would be decidable!
mathContext:
haltingOracle$(p, n)$ = h10Oracle$(P_{p,n})$

where $P_{p,n}$ encodes 'program $p$ halts on input $n$' as a Diophantine equation.

title: H10 is Undecidable
content:
**Main Theorem**: Hilbert's 10th Problem is undecidable.

No algorithm can determine whether an arbitrary Diophantine equation has integer solutions.

Proof: If such an algorithm existed, we could use it (via MRDP) to decide the halting problem. But halting is undecidable. Contradiction.

title: Matiyasevich's Breakthrough
content:
The hardest part of MRDP was showing that **exponential relations are Diophantine**. This was Matiyasevich's key contribution.

He used properties of Fibonacci numbers and Pell equation solutions to encode $y = x^n$ as a system of polynomial equations.

This was surprising because exponential growth seems 'too fast' for polynomials to capture.
mathContext:
The relation $y = x^n$ is Diophantine:
$\exists P : y = x^n \Leftrightarrow P(x, y, n, z_1, \ldots, z_k) = 0$

Key tool: Fibonacci numbers satisfy $F_{2n} = F_n(F_{n+1} + F_{n-1})$

title: Linear Case is Decidable
content:
Linear Diophantine equations ARE decidable! The equation $ax + by = c$ has integer solutions iff $\gcd(a,b)$ divides $c$.

This shows the undecidability is about **general** polynomials, not all Diophantine problems. The Euclidean algorithm solves the linear case in polynomial time.
mathContext:
$ax + by = c$ has solutions iff $\gcd(a,b) | c$

Solutions can be found via extended Euclidean algorithm.
